description:
Showcase '94 was the DC Comics relaunch of the old Showcase series. Under this new format, each issue would contain three separate stories, with each issue starring someone from the Batman Family. Neal Pozner was the editor for the series until his death in 1994. This new version of Showcase also featured a lot of up-and-coming new writers and artists who would go on to create other series. This Showcase reincarnation started with Showcase '93 and would continue on to Showcase '96.
¬†
Showcase '94 crossed-over with the DC-wide Zero Hour story arc in issues 8-10, and featured a number of the New Blood heroes in backup stories. Stars of this run include the inmates from Arkham Asylum, Arsenal, Atom, Azrael, Ballistic, Black Condor, Bloodwynd, Blue Beetle, Gunfire, Huntress, Joker, Loose Cannon, Man-Bat, the New Gods, Oracle, Pax, Penguin, Razorsharp and the Psyba-Rats, Robin, Scarface, Sparx, Starfire, Terrorsmith, Triumph and Wildcat.¬†
¬†

Collections and Reprints

  • The Zero Hour stories from issues #8-9 collected in the Zero Hour: Crisis in Time trade paperback (2003)
name: Showcase '94

description: Hitoshi Kobe doesn't do well in school. He's no good at sports. Girls don't even talk to him except to make fun of him. The one thing he is good at is computers. He's designed artificial intelligence programs and Number 30 is his favorite. Hitoshi promises Thirty that if she ever becomes a real girl, he'll be her boyfriend. One dark and stormy night, his house is struck by lightning and Thirty emerges from the computer screen ...

description:
A1 was a graphic novel anthology running between 1989-1992 from Atoeka Press featuring some of the biggest names in British and American comics. Most stories were showcase stand alone segments though a few strips were recurring.

A second volume A1 (1992) was published under Marvel's Epic Comics imprint.

Most of the content as been republished and reprinted in numerous volumes and collections from various publishers over the years since its initial publication.
name: A1

description:
No Hero is a seven-issue serialized graphic novel written by Warren Ellis and featuring artwork by Juan Jose Ryp.

Plot Summary

In 1966, a group of superhumans emerged in San Francisco, guided by the man whose unique new drugs gave them their incredible powers. Calling themselves The Levellers, this unified front stood against street crimes and corruption, in defense of their city against any and all assault. Years have passed, and we fast-forward through the tumultuous events of those early years to today, where the idealistic Levellers have gone through four incarnations to become The Front Line. But the team is not the only thing that‚Äôs advanced over the years, and there are no easy victories when their luck finally begins to run out‚Ä¶

"Superhuman Trilogy"

No Hero is typically regarded as the second part in Avatar's and Warren Ellis' "Superhuman Trilogy" dealing with the creation of superheroes. The other two books include Black Summer (which also featured art by Juan Jose Ryp) and Supergod (featuring art by Garrie Gastonny). In an interview before the release of the first issue of Supergod Warren Ellis said "Black Summer was about superhumans who were too human. No Hero was about superhumans who were inhuman. Supergod is about superhumans who are no longer human at all, but something else. The third leg of a thematic trilogy if you like." [link]

Collected Volumes

  • No Hero (trade paperback; collecting all issues)
name: No Hero

description:
Joe R. Lansdale puts a new spin on an old classic with this four-part adaptation of master-storyteller Robert E. Howard's classic tale of terror Pigeons from Hell. Set in the deep south, Pigeons tells the story of a damned house with a wicked past whose vile form casts a shadow of death on all who dare to enter. At dusk, as the sun slumps below the horizon, scores of pigeons can be seen flocking from the house in waning sunlight. The pigeons, they say, are the souls of the damned escaping from the very bowels of Hell itself.

Joe R. Lansdale (author of such works as Bubba Ho-Tep, The Nightrunners, and The Drive-In) is no stranger to comics, having worked on Batman, The Lone Ranger, Jonah Hex, and Robert E. Howard's Conan. He is joined by comics newcomer Nathan Fox. Together Lansdale and Fox are a powerhouse of visual storytelling, perfectly suited for the dark and dismal world of Robert E. Howard's horror classic Pigeons from Hell.
name: Pigeons from Hell

description:
Strikeback! is a series co-created by Jonathan Peterson and Kevin Maguire. The series was first published by Bravura (Malibu) but only 3 of the proposed 6 issues were ever put out. The creators later took the series to Image comics, which re-published issues 1-3, and wrapped up with issue 5.

The interior art and story for issues 1-3 is almost completely identical to the Bravura issues (1-3). The Image series is printed on a non-glossy paper and the cameo of the Finster is replaced with a cameo of Savage Dragon in issue 1. Also in issue 3, the two page spreads are correctly printed in order in the Image volume versus being broken up on different pages (and very hard to read) in the Bravura volume. Kevin Maguire drew all new covers for the Image issues.
name: Strikeback!

description:
An experimental series in which Matt Wagner tried to create a history for Madame Xanadu, a character with little back story in the DCU. This story was chosen to be told under DC Comics' Vertigo imprint because of its mature nature. While at Vertigo Madame Xanadu was allowed to involve DCU characters, this is something that became rare after the so called "invisible wall" was created between DCU and Vertigo. With the 2010 mandate recalling the originally DCU characters this series became causality of it and was canceled. The monthly sales were not the strongest, but it was in the middle of the Vertigo pack, while series like DMZ, Scalped and Northlanders which all had lowers sales did not get canceled.

Trade Paperbacks

  • #01-10: Disenchanted
  • #11-15: Exodus Noir
  • #16-23: Broken House of Cards
  • #24-29: Extra Sensory
name: Madame Xanadu

description: W.i.t.c.h. is published by Disney in Italy. It follows the story of five ordinary girls with an extraordinary mission to save not only the world they are in but also the other magical dimensions. It has been published in other languages as well. As the logo indicates, the title is actually an acronym of the five girls' names: Will Vandom, Irma Lair, Taranee Cook, Cornelia Hale and Hay Lin.
name: W.i.t.c.h.

description: Exactly 100 years after Wilhelm Rollman first demonstrated the anaglyphic method of creating 3-D images using glasses with 1 red and 1 blue lens, the Dynamic Duo leaped off the page in 3-D Batman. The comic tapped into the trend that was popular in movie theaters at the time. Shipped with a pair of 3-d glasses,the comic reprinted 3-D versions of three stories; "The Fowls of fate" from Batman #48, "The Inter-planetary aquarium" from Action #127 and "The robot robbers" from Batman #42.
name: 3-D Batman

description:
Victor von Doom Reminisces about his childhood, the loss of his mother, and his first visit to the United States. The series follows through Doom's ascending the throne of Latveria.

From the black steppes of Eastern Europe, to the college campuses of New York City, and finally to the throne of Latveria -- this is the life of Von Doom! From his earliest disasters to his scientific triumphs to the tragedy of the fractured man he would become, this is the story you know, and the one that you don‚Äôt. The story of the missing years and the journey that shaped the man who would be king. An epic Russian tragedy in comic form, this is unlike any Doom story you‚Äôve ever seen. Five-time Eisner-nominated Best Writer Ed Brubaker turns his shadowy vision to Marvel‚Äôs greatest villain, Victor Von Doom. With the phenomenal art team of Pablo Raimondi and Mark Farmer, you will witness Doom‚Äôs life from his earliest moments to the day he took the throne of Latveria. A dark and revealing examination of how an innocent boy grows up to be a tyrant -- a new twist on an old legend -- BOOKS OF DOOM is a sweeping epic of tragedy, madness and destiny!

Collected in Fantastic Four: Books of Doom
name: Books of Doom

description:
You are thousands of years old. You have amazing powers. You have watched civilizations rise and fall-- so why does no one remember any of this? Created by Jack "the King" Kirby in 1976, THE ETERNALS have triumphantly returned to current continuity. The godlike alien entities known as Celestials came to Earth long ago, giving birth to two battling races, the superhuman Eternals and the grotesque Deviants. The series lasted for only 9 issues with one Eternals Annual as well.

Collected Editions
